pages/assets/notion-meeting-note-test.ht.title: Notion Meeting Note Test
pages/assets/notion-meeting-note-test.ht.description:
Summary
95% of positions currently come from Murex, with the remaining 5% from other systems
Non-Murex positions include: IBD trades (managed in ACPS)
Physical commodities (from Osiris)
Corporate bank trades (loans and deposits)
Operational call deposits and finance adjustments (from Smart/Chameleon) Current risk runs are designed by entity sets (e.g., SA entity set) Position state gets imported into Murex
Market value component is used in attribution process
Cash balance comes from Smart/Chameleon
Current attribution process: For position states imported from external systems: Market Value + Cash Balance
For Murex positions: Market Value from Murex + Pass-Cache from Chameleon Including pass-cache in all runs would require splitting existing runs
This could potentially require: Adding ~90 new tasks in controlling (for SA only)
Creating ~90 new merge tasks to recombine outputs
Reconsidering the entity-set-based design Different system combinations present unique challenges: Osiris positions present special challenges as cash in those portfolios is part of scope
For IBD and Corporate Bank positions, both market value and cash balance come from external systems Create one run with two logical sources to handle different position types
Alternative approach: Import position sets, generate pass-cash balances from Murex, compare with Chameleon's cash balance, import the difference as corrective position, then run everything including pass-cache
This alternative might avoid splitting runs but requires careful implementation and testing Meeting leader to share notes and put details in an email Continue refining approach before the upcoming design session for RISC Investigate if the Osiris physical commodity positions are in the same portfolio as their derivatives

pages/acronyms.html.title: Acronyms
pages/acronyms.html.description: TS → Treasury Settlement (See TS Account)

pages/as-is-system-evaluation.html.title: As-Is System Evaluation
pages/as-is-system-evaluation.html.description:
Cash-based: All portfolios use TS Account's for settlements. Overnight funding default: Unless a term trade is booked, everything funds at ON rate. Manual intervention: Term trades need manual mirror deals.
Reactive controls: Reconciliations run off GL (IM10 & IM19) catch errors after EOD. Limited transparency: True intraday liquidity position not visible to Treasury.
Heavy reliance on Chameleon and GL for operational control.
Exception Management is slow (post-EOD).
No real-time funding attribution[2] (rates not decomposed into base/liquidity). Complex structure of suspense accounts reduces visibility. Treasury’s ability to manage intraday liquidity is constrained.

pages/ftp.html.title: FTP
pages/ftp.html.description: Repo funding trades are internalised via mirror deals between Repo Desk and Trading Desk. Repo Desk’s external trades are booked against GTSY portfolios. This allows Treasury to allocate true FTP cost of repo funding back to desks.

pages/gl.html.title: GL
pages/gl.html.description:
Balances from Chameleon flow into RADA GL (Oracle EBS). 3-way reconciliation is performed: Portfolio balance in Chameleon. Portfolio balance in RADA front-end.
Contra balance in GTSY Dept FND (back-end). portfolio cashflows vs funding events.settlements vs funding events in GTSY Dept FND.

pages/gtsy.html.description: GTSY Contra Entries

pages/gtsy-contra-entries.html.title: GTSY Contra Entries
pages/gtsy-contra-entries.html.description: For every debit in a desk’s TS Account, there is a contra credit in GTSY’s central funding portfolio (Dept FND). This ensures that GTSY “stands in the middle” of all funding. Example: If Desk borrows 100m → Desk TS account -100m, GTSY +100m.

pages/matched-maturity-funding.html.title: Matched Maturity Funding
pages/matched-maturity-funding.html.description:
Real-time, one-to-one matching of trades with funding. Each trade generates an internal loan/deposit with matching maturity and cashflow profile. Priced off the FTP Curve () Trader buys R 100 mil SA Gov Bond, maturity
To pay the seller, GTSY provides R 100 M loan with maturity. FTP Rate = 10Y swap + liquidity premium (say 9%)
Bonds Desk reconds: Asset: R 100 m bond Liability: R 100 m FTP loan at 9% → The Desk can only make money if the bond return is greater than 9%. In addition to overnight balances, RMB uses term funding:
GM (Global Markets):
Term trades manually booked in Murex using mirror deal functionality.
Ensures GTSY portfolio has matched but opposite position.
FTP rate applied.
IBD / TTS (ZAR):
Term trades booked directly in Chameleon, mirrored to GTSY.
IBD / TTS (Foreign Currency): Moving towards using Murex mirror deals.
Current gap: FTP rates captured, but components (base vs Liquidity Premium) not split. Trade Funding → runs in real time as trades are booked.

pages/position-funding.html.title: Position Funding
pages/position-funding.html.description:
End-of-day batch process. Funds open positions where no clear contractual maturity exists equities, revolving loans, unsettled capital Treasury applies a behavioural tenor (e.g. 1M, 3M) to approximate how long the position ties up liquidity. Rolled daily, but priced at the behavioural FTP Curve.
Equities Desk holds R 200 m of listed shares. That R200 m still required cash to buy the shares → Treasury provided it. But equities have no maturity date. Treasury assumes they behave like 1M rolling funding. At EOD, system books: Internal funding loan: R200m at . Asset: R 200 m equities. Liability: R 200 m behavioural funding loan. → Desk only shows profit if equity returns is greater than cost of rolling 1M funding. Position Funding → runs at EOD to capture behavioural positions.

pages/rada.html.title: RADA
pages/rada.html.description:
AKA "Oracle EBS" GL & Reconciliations Balances from Chameleon flow into RADA GL (Oracle EBS). 3-way reconciliation is performed: Portfolio balance in Chameleon. Portfolio balance in RADA front-end.
Contra balance in GTSY Dept FND (back-end). Daily ControlsDaily controls:portfolio cashflows vs funding events.settlements vs funding events in GTSY Dept FND.

pages/repo-sweeping.html.title: Repo Sweeping
pages/repo-sweeping.html.description:
Repo sweeping is the centralized mechanism by which all bond long/short positions across RMB’s Trading Desk's are transferred (“swept”) to the Repo Desk's, which acts as the single point of contact with the external repo market.This ensures: Collateral optimisation – the bank sees all eligible securities in one place. Liquidity efficiency – one central desk negotiates repo rates. Risk control – traders don’t face external repo counterparties directly. Transparency – funding costs recorded via FTP and internal mirror trades. Bond Desk agrees to buy R100m SA Government Bond ( settlement). On settlement day, Repo Desk simultaneously: Receives the bond into its custody account. Repos it out to a market counterparty, receiving cash. Uses that cash to pay the seller. Internally:
Repo Desk allocates the bond to the Bonds Desk (mirror entry). Bond Desk shows: Bond asset + Repo loan liability. Repo Desk shows: Internal loan asset + External repo liability. Custody flow (DvP at CSD): Seller → Repo Desk custody → Repo Counterparty (pledge). Cash: Repo Counterparty → Repo Desk → Seller. Bond Desk agrees to sell R50m bond it doesn’t own.
Repo Desk arranges a Reverse Repo with the market: Repo Desk lends cash externally. Market counterparty delivers the bond into Repo Desk custody. Internally: Repo Desk lends the borrowed bond to the Bond Desk (mirror). Bond Desk delivers the bond to the client and receives sale cash. Custody flow (DvP at CSD): Repo Counterparty → Repo Desk custody → Client. Cash: Client → Trading Desk. Market access: Concentrates borrowing/lending activity → better pricing. Collateral management: Avoids desks competing for the same bonds. Operational simplicity: Only one external settlement point (Repo Desk custody account).
FTP consistency: Funding costs (repo rate + liquidity spread) embedded via mirror trades. Repo funding trades are internalised via mirror deals between Repo Desk and Trading Desk.
Repo Desk’s external trades are booked against GTSY portfolios. This allows Treasury to allocate true FTP cost of repo funding back to desks.
Repo Desk custody accounts sit at the CSD / Settlement Agent (e.g., Strate, Euroclear, Clearstream). Trading desks never instruct CSD directly — they only see internal mirror positions. Daily sweeps reconcile all long/short positions into Repo Desk accounts, ensuring: Zero unrecognised cash balances. Central visibility of collateral. Flat trading desks (no external exposures). ✅ Summary:Repo sweeping makes the Repo Desk a central “collateral warehouse”. Trading desks hold market risk, but the Repo Desk holds custody and funding responsibility. All desks are “funded” internally at FTP repo rates, while Repo Desk optimises externally.
Notion - Repo Sweeping Process↩︎

headers.heading: 🔹 Long Position Example (Trader Buys a Bond)
🔹 Short Position Example (Trader Sells a Bond)
🔹 Why Use a Central Repo Desk?

pages/residual-cash-funding.html.title: Residual Cash Funding
pages/residual-cash-funding.html.description:
Final sweep[1] at end of day. Captures any remaining cash balances not already funded.
Always priced at the Overnight FTP rate (repo/OIS). Typically covers realised P&L and timing mismatches.
FX Desk realises ZAR 5 m profit today.
At EOD, system sweeps it into GTSY as an overnight deposit. Desk earns FTP (O/N) until it redeploys the cash. → Ensures no stray balances remain in portfolios. Residual Funding → runs last at EOD to sweep any leftovers.
Repo Sweeping↩︎

pages/settlement-agents.html.title: Settlement Agents

pages/simple-process-flow.html.title: Simple Process Flow
pages/simple-process-flow.html.description:
Trade → TS Account → GTSY Contra → Payment → Nostro Trade booked in Trading System → theoretical cashflow.
Cashflow sent to Chameleon → updates TS Account. Chameleon calculates overnight interest.
GTSY records the opposite funding entry.
Calypso processes payment → external Nostro account settles. Oracle EBS records P&L, funding clearing, interdepartmental funding, payment clearing, Nostro clearing.

pages/to-be-system.html.title: To-Be System
pages/to-be-system.html.description: Types of Funding > Three Methods

pages/treasury.html.title: Treasury
pages/treasury.html.description:
Desks don’t wire cash daily to Treasury. Instead, Treasury applies FTP charges/credits through Chameleon: If a desk has a negative balance → funding expense (charged interest). If a desk has a positive balance → funding income (credited interest).
Daily: Interest accrues in Chameleon on TS balances.[2]
Month-end: Interest is capitalised (posted to P&L).[3] Lifecycle: Trade Day ():
Cashflow hits TS Account. EOD:
Balance charged FTP. onward: accrues daily. Month-end: final interest posting. Desks don’t transfer actual cash to Treasury. The funding cost is deducted from their P&L. When desks price trades, they must include funding costs (FTP) in the client rate. Example: Client loan at 7%. FTP = 6%. Desk margin = 1% (after paying Treasury).
Different Desks↩︎
TS Account↩︎
Overnight Rates↩︎

pages/treasury-settlement-call-account.h.title: Treasury Settlement Call Account
pages/treasury-settlement-call-account.h.description: Every trading portfolio (e.g., Bonds, FX, Equities) has a Treasury Settlement (TS) call account in Chameleon. This TS account reflects all cash inflows and outflows for that portfolio. All internal and external settlements are routed through the TS account. https://www.notion.so/2809ae4c7424808a9d81c402dbc1756f?v=2809ae4c742480cba177000cf0a3cefe↩︎

headers.heading: In Chameleon:

pages/types-of-funding.html.title: Types of Funding
pages/types-of-funding.html.description:
Source[1]
RMB is transitioning from cash-based TS Account's (Chameleon) to a trade-based funding model in Murex.
Under the new framework, all portfolios are fully funded by Group Treasury (GTSY) using three processes
Trade Funding
Position Funding
Residual Funding
These methods ensure that every trading and banking position is funded at the correct cost, using the appropriate FTP curve.
AKA Trade Funding Real-time, one-to-one matching of trades with funding. Each trade generates an internal loan/deposit with matching maturity and cashflow profile.
Priced off the FTP Curve () Trader buys R 100 mil SA Gov Bond, maturity
To pay the seller, GTSY provides R 100 M loan with maturity. FTP Rate = 10Y swap + liquidity premium (say 9%)
Bonds Desk reconds: Asset: R 100 m bond Liability: R 100 m FTP loan at 9% → The Desk can only make money if the bond return is greater than 9%.
AKA Behavioural Funding End-of-day batch process. Funds open positions where no clear contractual maturity exists equities, revolving loans, unsettled capital Treasury applies a behavioural tenor (e.g. 1M, 3M) to approximate how long the position ties up liquidity.
Rolled daily, but priced at the behavioural FTP Curve.
Equities Desk holds R 200 m of listed shares. That R200 m still required cash to buy the shares → Treasury provided it. But equities have no maturity date. Treasury assumes they behave like 1M rolling funding. At EOD, system books: Internal funding loan: R200m at . Asset: R 200 m equities. Liability: R 200 m behavioural funding loan. → Desk only shows profit if equity returns is greater than cost of rolling 1M funding.
AKA Overnight Sweep Final sweep1 at end of day. Captures any remaining cash balances not already funded.
Always priced at the Overnight FTP rate (repo/OIS). Typically covers realised P&L and timing mismatches.
FX Desk realises ZAR 5 m profit today.
At EOD, system sweeps it into GTSY as an overnight deposit. Desk earns FTP (O/N) until it redeploys the cash. → Ensures no stray balances remain in portfolios. Trade Funding → runs in real time as trades are booked. Position Funding → runs at EOD to capture behavioural positions. Residual Funding → runs last at EOD to sweep any leftovers. At the end of each day, all portfolios are fully funded and all liquidity sits with Treasury.Even if the desk “already has the asset”: To buy an asset, you needed cash → Treasury provided it. That cash has a cost → reflected via an FTP loan. Without this, desks would appear to make “free” returns, ignoring liquidity cost. Funding ensures true profitability is visible.
Notion - Funding Models↩︎

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
